title: GitHub - sts10/tidy: Combine and clean word lists

last_post.content:
I think my most impressive open source project is Tidy, a CLI that combines and cleans large word lists.

https://github.com/sts10/tidy

It's written in #Rust and includes some interesting options, like:

* guarantee a maximum shared prefix length
* guarantee a minimum edit distance between words
* make list uniquely decodable by removing prefix words, suffix words, or using the Sardinas-Patterson algorithm
* aid list creators in avoiding certain brute force attacks
Bet @zacharylipton@twitter.com never expected "The Mythos of Model Interpretability" to be cited in a Dermatology textbook. https://arxiv.org/pdf/1606.03490.pdf

title: How Twitter misleads us about how many people have left — and what to do about it

last_post.content:
Who do so many people seem unaware of the mass exodus from Twitter?

Social media feeds are engines for distorting our social understanding. But we can push back against the algorithm, with a simple automated out-of-office message on Twitter (how-to included).

This post explains the science of social influence that allows Twitter to maintain an illusion of a full room, how to change that, & why we need industry-independent science for our digital environments.

https://natematias.medium.com/how-twitter-misleads-us-about-how-many-people-have-left-and-what-to-do-about-it-bba484b6fed6

title: The Vegetal Designs of Victor Horta, Pioneer of Art Nouveau | SciHi Blog

last_post.content:
On January 6, 1861, Belgian architect and designer Victor Horta was born. Horta is one of the founders of the Art Nouveau movement. The curving stylized vegetal forms that Horta used influenced many others, including architect Hector Guimard, who used it in the first house he designed in Paris and in the entrances he designed for the Paris Metro.

http://scihi.org/victor-horta/

title: The science of why you have great ideas in the shower

last_post.content:
TIL there's a technical name for why ideas happen in the shower: the "default mode network" is a pattern of brain activity, measurable using fMRI, that happens when we're unfocussed. When the brain goes into idle mode (reduced activity), this part of the brain actually becomes *more* active. What does the default mode network do? Research is ongoing, but part of it definitely seems to be making connections, which is associated with curiosity and creativity.

More here: https://www.nationalgeographic.co.uk/history-and-civilisation/2022/08/the-science-of-why-you-have-great-ideas-in-the-shower

title: 'How are we going to live?' Families dispossessed of their land to make way for Total’s Congo offsetting project

last_post.content:
With #FossilFuels, it's #colonialism all the way down.

Total plants acacia trees in Congo for "#CarbonOffsets".

The legacy of colonial law means that the state is the official owner of most land.

The government signed a lease promising to evict local people with ancestral claims to the land, pays families around $1 per hectare.

Meanwhile, farmers who used to work this land can no longer cultivate their fields and say they are struggling to feed their families.

https://unearthed.greenpeace.org/2022/12/12/total-congo-offsetting-land-dispossessed/

Magrit v0.13.0 has been released and is now online on https://magrit.cnrs.fr/ 🗺️
This version notably makes available a new type of contiguous cartograms, those based on the algorithm developed by Gastner, Seguy and More (2018).
The computation is performed solely in the browser thanks to a WebAssembly module (https://www.npmjs.com/package/go-cart-wasm). This is the first use of WebAssembly in Magrit, hoping that it will be satisfactory for the users!
